conclusion: Shadows are formed when an object blocks light, and their shape and size depend on the shape of the object and the position of the light source.
The size of the shadow is influenced by the distance between the object and the light source; closer light source results in a larger shadow.
Shadows A, B, C, and D are currently cast behind the objects, indicating the light source is positioned in front of the objects.
When the light source moves forward, it gets closer to the objects.
As the light source moves forward, the angle of light rays hitting the objects changes, causing the shadows to shift.
The shadows will move closer to the objects because the light rays will be more perpendicular to the ground.
The shadows will become smaller due to the light source being closer to the objects, reducing the spread of light rays.
The shadows A, B, C, and D will move closer to their respective objects.
The shadows A, B, C, and D will become smaller.
When the light source moves forward above the objects, the shadows A, B, C, and D will move closer to the objects and become smaller.
